Modify strict canon imitation to let Tortoise discuss Bach while Achilles discusses Escher
Replace Day and Night with the untitled Escher tessellation plate
failures: Initial problem of extreme repetition when two voices crossed in the middle of the Crab Canon
Two early versions of the Crab Canon were interesting but weak, leading to abandonment for over a year
Difficulty in imagining general algorithms that create meaningful new symbols from colliding symbols, like recombinant DNA
aha_moments: Realization that the word 'crab' in 'crab canon' could be connected to 'tortoise' through abstract shared quality, leading to the invention of the Crab character
Discovery that the Dialogue was becoming self-referential unintentionally, sharing a conceptual skeleton with Gödel's incompleteness theorem
Recognition of Day and Night as a pictorial crab canon with complementary voices
Viewing Escher's tessellation plate in a new way as a genuine crab canon in both form and content
Finding palindromic structures in DNA sequences while reading Watson's book
Level-crossing moment recognizing that A, T, C map to Achilles, Tortoise, Crab, and G maps to Gene
metaphors: Postal system as metaphor for message-passing languages (General Delivery, self-addressed stamped envelopes, parcel post)
Enzymes as comparable to actors in object-oriented systems
Venus's flytrap as metaphor for enzyme's hair-trigger activation
DNA strands recombining to form new viable organisms as metaphor for symbol fusion
Cell division stages (meiosis phases) as metaphor for the development stages of the Crab Canon
Genotype coding for phenotype applied to DNA structure coding for Dialogue structure
temporal: Before enzyme cascades, no model existed for synthesizing efficient code pieces from learned behavior
Before the author inserted the Crab character, there would have been ugly repetition at the center crossing
After abandoning the Crab Canon for over a year, the author returned with new ideas about referencing Bach
Before recognizing the pattern, the author had possessed MacGillavry's monograph for years without seeing Plate 23 as a crab canon
Once the coincidence of form and content was recognized in the Escher plate, it transformed from Day and Night to become central to the work
quotes: This kind of "hair-trigger" program has been used in AI, and goes by the name of demon. The important thing here is the idea of having many different "species" of triggerable subroutines just lying around waiting to be triggered.
When two concepts really become 'one? Is there some precise instant when a fusion takes place?
at the dead center, I could block the repetitive effect, by inserting one special line, said by a new character: a Crab!

extraction.summary: This section explores how conceptual mapping—the process of discovering and exploiting shared abstract structures between different ideas—enables creative synthesis and understanding. Through the evolution of the Crab Canon, the author demonstrates how ideas can be recursively mapped onto each other at varying levels of abstraction, revealing isomorphisms that connect diverse domains like music, dialogue, molecular biology, and visual art.
key_claims: Conceptual skeletons are abstract structures that can connect two different ideas at varying levels of abstraction
A conceptual skeleton is an invariant core with constant features that can serve as the basis for multiple different concrete instances
Concepts have multiple representations accessible through different 'ports of access' that are often partitioned from each other
Forced matching occurs when high-level similarity between ideas is compelling enough to drive mapping even without apparent lower-level continuation
Mental partitions prevent thoughts from spilling over in free association, containing and channeling the flow of thought
Symbols are composed of tight and loose elements from different levels of nested contexts, with loose elements easily replaceable
processes: Conceptual mapping: identifying shared abstract structures, then recursively mapping corresponding parts at deeper levels
Fusion of symbols: lining ideas up, judiciously choosing pieces from each, and recombining them in new ways (analogous to genetic recombination)
Abstraction: viewing specific notions along various dimensions to extract conceptual skeletons
Forced matching: pushing analogies even when lower-level continuation is not apparent, then adjusting tentatively
Multiple representation retrieval: accessing concepts through different 'handles' or ports based on context
decisions: Deciding which level of abstraction to work at when mapping two disparate ideas
Choosing which conceptual skeleton to retrieve when multiple representations exist for an object
Determining which slots or elements in symbols correspond and should be mapped onto each other
Deciding how deeply to carry out a mapping (avoiding mapping too deeply or too shallowly)
failures: Retrieving inappropriate conceptual skeletons that focus on irrelevant dimensions (e.g., physical shape of spare tire instead of functional role)
Weak mental partitions between language representations causing bilingual confusion and unintended code-switching
Flimsy partitions allowing undesired free association between different aspects of a concept
aha_moments: Realizing that Plate 23 of Escher's tessellation was a genuine crab canon in both form and content, crystallizing the book's main idea of uniting form and content
Discovering crab-canonical structures in DNA palindromes, connecting biological structure to the dialogue
The level-crossing realization that A, T, C matched both DNA bases and character names, and G could stand for 'Gene', creating a mapping between DNA structure and dialogue structure
Seeing that the Crab Canon's development paralleled meiosis, enabling description through biological terminology
Recognizing that concepts have multiple independent representations with partitions preventing unintended cross-activation
metaphors: Conceptual skeletons as invariant cores with parameters/variables that can be 'slipped'
Crab canon as two strands crossing in the middle, joined by a 'knot', mapped onto homologous chromosomes joined by a centromere
Symbol fusion as genetic recombination involving exchange of genes
Ports of access as handles for retrieving concepts from memory
Mental partitions as barriers containing and channeling thought flow
The Vice President as a spare tire on the automobile of government
temporal: For years the author flipped through MacGillavry's monograph before one day seeing Plate 23 in a new way
After becoming infatuated with molecular biology, the author discovered palindromic DNA structures
Months later, while discussing DNA imagery, the author experienced the final level-crossing insight about letter mappings
The whole process of Crab Canon development unfolded as successive mappings over extended time
Before rigid partitions, bilingual adults learning two languages simultaneously confuse words; after partition solidification, they maintain separation
quotes: a structure having two parts which do the same thing, only moving in opposite directions
a plural thing made singular and re-pluralized wrongly
The loose ones can be dislodged and replaced rather easily, which, depending on the circumstances, can create a "subjunctive instant replay", a forced match, or an analogy

extraction.summary: This section explores how creativity and analogy-making work through conceptual mapping and symbol manipulation, arguing that creativity is mechanizable despite appearing unmechanical. It examines how humans excel at pattern recognition across all levels and use language fluidly, while current AI programs remain rigid and limited in their understanding of nuance, context, and emotional significance.
key_claims: Creativity has a mechanical substrate even though it appears unmechanical
Randomness is intrinsic to thought, not something that needs to be artificially added to programs
Concepts are composed of tight and loose elements from different levels of nested contexts
Humans can recognize patterns across all levels of abstraction; programs typically excel in one domain while missing obvious patterns in another
Language in human hands is 'spongy' and imprecise yet communicates effectively; SHRDLU uses language 'metallically'
Understanding simple stories requires extensive background knowledge about the world and human emotions
Computer programs cannot produce genuine creativity in domains like music until they have emotions as complex as humans
processes: Conceptual mapping process: notice high-level similarity, pursue on lower levels until finding strong analogy, strengthen with forced matching
Symbol manipulation involving slippage: loose elements are dislodged and replaced from nested contexts
Pattern recognition that involves nested contexts, conceptual skeletons, conceptual mapping, slippability, and multiple representations
decisions: When mapping concepts, decide how deeply to map symbols onto each other
Choose which elements to keep tight and which to leave loose in conceptual representations
Distinguish between forced matches, analogies, and metaphors in analogical reasoning
failures: SHRDLU cannot handle 'hazy' language or imprecise phrases
SHRDLU is oblivious to repetition and cannot form new concepts or recognize patterns across domains
Programs excel in one domain while missing obvious patterns in another
Current AI programs cannot understand stories that require reading between the lines or grasping emotional significance
Programs use words metallically rather than with human flexibility
aha_moments: Randomness appears to be intrinsic to human thinking through interaction with a random world, not something added artificially
What appears random is often symmetric viewed through a 'skew' filter—pseudorandomness
Small creative acts are everywhere in human thinking, not just at the highest plane
The difference between highly creative ideas and ordinary ones may be a combined sense of beauty, simplicity, and harmony
Human language works despite being imprecise because we use it 'spongily' rather than metallically
metaphors: Concepts as having tight and loose elements like frames with different levels of nested contexts
Creativity as mechanizable despite appearing unmechanical, like the hidden mechanics of hiccups
Human language as 'spongy,' 'rubbery,' or 'Nutty-Puttyish' versus SHRDLU's 'metallic' language
Language in human hands as almost like a fluid despite coarse-grained components
Analogies compared to musical chords: superficially similar notes are harmonically distant, deeply related ideas are superficially disparate
Logic in the brain as a succession of operations with symbolic pictures, like an abstract Chinese alphabet with meta-logic
The mechanical versus unmechanical nature of human thought like crystals versus fluids
temporal: Before AI research focused on single sentence understanding; recently turned toward understanding children's stories
Before computers were transparent to creators; as programs become less transparent, approach to creativity has begun
Programs are 'getting closer' to simulating human thought, though they currently seem quite mechanical
quotes: The mechanical substrate of creativity may be hidden from view, but it exists.
Language, in human hands, becomes almost like a fluid, despite the coarse grain of its components.
The process of logic itself working internally in the brain may be more analogous to a succession of operations with symbolic pictures... forming a sort of meta- or super-logic with its own rules.

extraction.summary: This section presents ten speculative questions about AI's future capabilities, arguing that truly intelligent programs would share human-like limitations and complexities rather than superhuman powers. It concludes with a whimsical dialogue introducing a musical composition concept.
key_claims: Computer programs cannot write beautiful music without emotions as complex as humans
Emotions emerge as byproducts of system organization, not from direct programming
An intelligent program may perform arithmetic slowly, similar to humans, due to rich conceptual representation
General intelligence programs capable of beating anyone at chess would be temperamental and bored with the game
Personality cannot be 'tuned' by adjusting memory parameters; it relies on constancy of memories
Intelligence and consciousness will remain intuitive rather than fully understood, even after creating intelligent programs
AI programs would likely be more alien to humans than humans are to each other due to different 'bodies'
Intelligence depends on 'total overview capacity' and the ability to jump out of the system
decisions: Whether to give an intelligent program a pocket calculator subsystem (creates reliability vs. intelligence tradeoff)
Determining whether we're dealing with true AI or just a 'weird' program (epistemological challenge)
failures: Direct simulation of emotions (like PARRY) cannot approach human emotional complexity
Shallow imitations of musical syntax fail to capture true musical expression
Underestimating the complexity of personality and human depth
Heavy memory manipulation damages intelligent systems, like irresponsible neurosurgery
aha_moments: Intelligent programs would inherit human limitations rather than transcend them
A program that passes the Turing test would appear to have a 'heart' even though we know its substrate is trivial operations
Superintelligence may be incomprehensible to humans due to different conceptual frameworks
The impossibility of truly understanding consciousness intuitively, even with working examples
metaphors: Music as a language of emotions requiring lived experience
Shallow pond analogy for understanding substrate-level operations
Piano in a mirror - inverted representation
Wittgenstein's lion - the incomprehensibility of alien intelligence
Bach squared - hypothetical music far beyond human comprehension
temporal: Before: specialists remember entry to field; After: outsiders articulate field's appeal
First race (Zeno): Achilles catches the Tortoise; Second race (Lewis Carroll): Achilles cannot catch up
quotes: A 'program' which could produce music as they did would have to wander around the world on its own, fighting its way through the maze of life and feeling every moment of it.
I think; therefore I have no access to the level where I sum.
If a lion could speak, we would not understand him.

extraction.summary: This section explores whether machines can possess originality and will through a dialogue between Achilles, the Tortoise, and Sloth, followed by an examination of Arthur Samuel's argument against machine consciousness. The author argues that both the Carroll Dialogue's infinite regress problem and Samuel's argument fail to account for the distinction between hardware (inviolate rules) and software (modifiable rules).
key_claims: Samuel argues machines cannot possess originality because nothing comes out of a machine that hasn't been put in
Samuel claims there must be a complete hiatus between carrying out man's wishes and machines developing their own will
The Carroll Tortoise argument about infinite regress in reasoning applies equally to machines and humans
Both machines and humans avoid infinite regress because their lowest-level rules are embedded in hardware that runs according to physics
Humans change their mental rules at software levels but hardware rules (neurons) remain constant
Software flexibility derives from hardware rigidity, not despite it
decisions: Devil's advocate approach to examining Samuel's argument about machine consciousness
Distinction between examining differences at software vs. hardware levels
failures: Samuel's assumption that machines need rules to apply rules, leading to infinite regress
Samuel's criterion that only self-designed beings can have true will, which would apply equally to humans who didn't design themselves
The Carroll Tortoise's reasoning about infinite regress in justifying logical steps
aha_moments: Both humans and machines escape infinite regress through hardware that operates according to physical laws without needing meta-permission
The same criterion Samuel uses to deny machine will would also deny human will, revealing the flaw in his argument
Hardware rigidity enables software flexibility rather than preventing it
Will could be mechanized through organization and structure across multiple levels, just as human will emerges from the brain
metaphors: Machine as genie or magical entity (what Samuel assumes, but rejects)
Will as emerging from physical substrate organization rather than magic
Software as modifiable rules at various levels, hardware as inviolate foundation
Tangled hierarchy concept applied to consciousness and rule-following
temporal: Samuel's 1960 rebuttal to Wiener's article on machines transcending designer limitations
The shift from Samuel's pessimism about machine consciousness to the author's argument that mechanization of will is possible
quotes: A machine is not a genie, it does not work by magic, it does not possess a will, and, Wiener to the contrary, nothing comes out which has not been put in
To believe otherwise is either to believe in magic or to believe that the existence of man's will is an illusion and that man's actions are as mechanical as the machine's
Hardware rules cannot-in fact, to their rigidity is due the software's flexibility! Not a paradox at all, but a fundamental, simple fact about the mechanisms of intelligence

extraction.summary: The author explores how hierarchical systems contain inviolate levels that cannot be changed by the system itself. Using the metaphor of a self-modifying chess game that evolves into a tangled hierarchy, the text demonstrates that even when rules can change rules recursively, there must always be some protected foundational level (like interpretation conventions) that remains unchanged and external to the system.
key_claims: Words and thoughts follow formal rules at the lowest hardware level
Software rules on various levels can change; hardware rules cannot
The rigidity of hardware rules is what enables software flexibility
In any system, there is always a 'protected' inviolate level unassailable by rules on other levels
A tangled hierarchy must have an external inviolate level governing it
The mind is a symbol tangle (software) supported by a neural tangle (hardware)
Strange loops occur when hierarchy-violating surprises fold back on themselves
Simple tangles like feedback do not create strange loops because they don't violate presumed level distinctions
processes: Self-modifying chess game: start with basic rules, add metarules for changing rules, add metametarules for changing metarules, collapse into single board where moves change rules
Creating inviolate levels: agree on interpretation conventions, establish turn-taking rules, create protected foundational level
Tangling inviolate and tangled levels: make interpretation conventions subject to revision, which requires new higher-level conventions, creating a new inviolate level
decisions: In self-modifying chess, constraints must be applied when allowing rule changes (anarchy would be pointless)
An agreement must exist between players on how to interpret chess positions as rules or metarules
failures: Allowing arbitrary rule changes without constraints in games leads to pointlessness
Attempting to eliminate all inviolate levels through 'supertangling' still requires agreement on new foundational conventions
aha_moments: The flexibility of software depends on the rigidity of hardware - not a paradox but a fundamental fact
You have access to your thoughts but not your neurons, like Achilles in the Prelude ant Fugue
A tangled hierarchy always requires an external inviolate level - discovered through various metaphors (chess, authorship triangle, Escher drawing hands)
The mind as symbols creating a tangle while being supported by an inviolate neural substrate
Strange loops require the surprise element of hierarchy violation, distinguishing them from simple feedback tangles
metaphors: Software and hardware distinction - flexible rules vs. rigid substrate
Chess board hierarchy - rules, metarules, metametarules as stacked levels
Authorship triangle - Z, T, E authors in cyclical novels all existing in H's novel
Drawing hands - mutual creation where artist (Escher) is external to the two hands
Jungle of neurons - forest of symbols linked by tangled vines representing thoughts
Klein bottle - topological wrongness when inside-outside distinction blurs
Tropical jungle - complex interconnected neural substrate
temporal: Before: hierarchical systems seemed to have clear level distinctions
After: introduction of self-modification reveals tangled hierarchies that fold back on themselves
Each time a 'supertangling' is attempted, new higher inviolate levels emerge
The collapse from multiple boards into a single board changes the nature from clean hierarchy to strange loop
quotes: You have access to your thoughts but not to your neurons.
To their rigidity is due the software's flexibility! Not a paradox at all, but a fundamental, simple fact about the mechanisms of intelligence.
No matter that the T-level itself is a Tangled Hierarchy-it is still governed by a set of conventions outside of itself. And that is the important point.

extraction.summary: The text explores tangled hierarchies and strange loops across multiple domains—from neural-symbolic systems to government and science. It distinguishes between simple tangles (like feedback) and tangled hierarchies (which violate presumed level distinctions), and examines how these paradoxes emerge when systems become self-referential or when multiple levels claim authority over each other.
key_claims: A tangled hierarchy differs from simple feedback in that it involves violations of presumed hierarchical level distinctions with a surprise element
Strange loops occur when something in a system acts on the system as if from outside it, blurring inside-outside distinctions
Humans feel self-programmed because they are shielded from lower neural levels, similar to how LISP programs appear self-modifying when viewed at the program level rather than the interpreter level
The legal system functions as a collective gesture granted by society and can be overridden like a river overflowing its banks
Evidence interpretation is not fully formalizable; it relies on beauty, simplicity, and subjective judgment alongside logic
Fringe science calling into question standard scientific procedures creates a tangled hierarchy of evaluation methods
Self-image formation involves complex information flows between internal needs and external evidence, with constant distortion and magnification cycles
processes: Stepping far enough back from a tangled situation to see clues that allow untangling
Using statistical mechanics and molecular-level description when macroscopic laws fail in non-equilibrium systems
Building on innate hardware for evidence interpretation while learning when to override basic mechanisms
Psychic mechanisms simultaneously processing internal self-esteem needs with external signals about identity
decisions: How far back to step before describing a tangled situation
Whether to compromise between opposing views or accept that compromise may be impossible
How to evaluate new ways of interpreting evidence without infinite regress
When to override basic evidence interpretation mechanisms
failures: ESP claiming to disappear when subjected to rigorous laboratory scrutiny
The technique of 'kicking the problem upstairs' by attacking the belief system rather than addressing the matter at hand
Watergate-era threat of presidential non-compliance with Supreme Court rulings
The impossibility of rigid rules for evidence interpretation due to inevitable exceptions
aha_moments: Recognition that symbol tangles are tangled hierarchies while neural tangles are simple tangles
Understanding that zooming out can reveal the resolution to apparently paradoxical situations
Realizing that legal systems and hierarchies ultimately depend on lower-level social consensus, not top-down authority
Recognizing that evidence evaluation is fundamentally an art relying on beauty and simplicity, not pure logic
Understanding that even AI systems will face the same problems of objectivity and interpretation that humans do
metaphors: The Klein bottle as representation of inside-outside distinction being blurred
Escher's Drawing Hands as illustration of self-referential illusion
River overflowing banks as analogy for legal system being overridden by social forces
Gas in non-equilibrium violating macroscopic laws as analogy for societies in anarchy violating formal rules
Kicking the problem upstairs as technique of moving criticism to higher levels of analysis
Information flowing in a complex swirl at different personality levels
temporal: Before stepping back vs. after stepping back in analyzing tangled situations
In equilibrium vs. in non-equilibrium for systems following physical laws
During laboratory observation vs. outside laboratory for ESP phenomena
Before Watergate era vs. during Watergate era for constitutional crises
quotes: A Tangled Hierarchy occurs when what you presume are clean hierarchical levels take you by surprise and fold back in a hierarchy-violating way.
The legal system is, in a sense, a polite gesture granted collectively by millions of people-and it can be overridden just as easily as a river can overflow its banks.
The process by which we decide what is valid or what is true is an art; and that it relies as deeply on a sense of beauty and simplicity as it does on rock-solid principles of logic or reasoning.

extraction.summary: This section explores how self-interpretation creates fundamental conflicts within human consciousness, drawing parallels between Gödel's Theorem and the impossibility of complete self-understanding. The author argues that consciousness itself—being self-reflective—necessarily generates internal inconsistencies that drive human individuality and behavior.
key_claims: Humans face extraordinary choices in interpreting evidence at every moment
The self-image is created through complex, recursive flows of internal and external information that create distortions and inconsistencies
Self-reflecting conscious beings necessarily contain unresolved, possibly unresolvable inconsistencies
Gödel's Theorem can serve as a metaphorical analogue for limitations in self-understanding, but should not be translated literally into other disciplines
Determining one's own sanity is a Strange Loop—using one's own logic to judge if that logic is peculiar
Complete self-understanding may be impossible due to a Gödelian loop limiting introspection depth
All limitative theorems (Gödel, Church, Turing, Tarski) suggest self-knowledge is inherently incomplete
Most humans are inconsistent, which is necessary and adaptive in a complex world
Personal nonexistence is logically comprehensible but psychologically incomprehensible
Results dependent on fusion of subject and object in science are uniformly limitative
processes: Information flows recursively between different personality levels, getting magnified, reduced, negated, or distorted at each iteration
The psyche attempts to reconcile internal self-esteem needs with external evidence about oneself
Self-questioning about sanity can create an ever-tightening vortex of self-fulfilling prophecies
Attempting to imagine personal nonexistence requires mapping oneself onto someone else
decisions: Science has progressed from studying observer-independent phenomena to investigating the observer itself
When interpreting evidence about oneself, the psyche must decide how to reconcile conflicting internal and external signals
failures: Attempting complete self-monitoring of brain state is 'a pipe dream, an absurd and uninteresting proposition'
Trying to fully deal with existential nonexistence 'leads nowhere' so most people 'sweep the whole mess under the rug'
The insane use consistently peculiar logic but cannot recognize it as peculiar from within their own system
aha_moments: Self-reflection and the resulting internal inconsistencies are paradoxically both universal to humans and the major force creating distinct individuals
The observer-observed dichotomy in science mirrors the symbol-object dichotomy in philosophy and art
All major limitative theorems in mathematics, logic, and physics involve fusion of subject and object
Personal identity contains the same kind of self-reference problem that makes formal systems incomplete
metaphors: Information swirling around and around in the personality, getting progressively distorted
The self cannot see itself just as eyes cannot see their own faces
TNT's metatheory mirrors itself but only incompletely, like humans attempting to jump out of themselves
Escher's dragon trying to jump from its native 2D plane into 3D
Zen masters reveling in the irreconcilability between Eastern and Western views of self and world
Limitative theorems as 'ancient fairy tales warning against self-knowledge'
temporal: Until this century, science was exclusively concerned with observer-independent phenomena
In this century, both music and art have gone through crises reflecting concern with the symbol-object problem
Step by step, Western science has moved inexorably toward investigation of the observer
quotes: If a person never contradicts himself, it must be that he says nothing. - Miguel de Unamuno
I cannot understand myself. - Zen master to Doko
Just as we cannot see our faces with our own eyes, is it not reasonable to expect that we cannot mirror our complete mental structures in the symbols which carry them out?

extraction.summary: This section explores the symbol-object dichotomy in modern art and music, particularly through René Magritte's paintings that play with the distinction between representation and reality. It connects this artistic exploration to philosophical questions about how symbols work and how minds understand the world, arguing that understanding general principles of how minds work is feasible despite Gödelian limitations.
key_claims: All limitative results in mathematics/physics (like Gödel's Theorems and Heisenberg's uncertainty principle) depend on the fusion of subject and object
Modern art and music have undergone crises reflecting concern with the symbol-object dichotomy
John Cage pioneered using sounds without symbolic meaning, exploring 'mention' rather than 'use' of sounds
Objects exhibited in galleries automatically acquire an aura of significance regardless of artist intent
The frame effect makes it impossible to suppress interpretation in art objects
Understanding general working principles of brains is feasible and not precluded by Gödel's Theorem
We experience the world as outside ourselves even though it is only a mental representation inside our minds
processes: Magritte's technique of placing a painting in front of a window to hide and represent simultaneously what lies behind it
Creating nested paintings within paintings to confuse symbol and reality layers
Using literal paint on painted palettes to blur representation and object
Enclosing symbols in quotes to make them mention themselves rather than be used
decisions: Choosing to view Magritte's work as consciousness of the symbol-object mystery rather than pure meaninglessness
Deciding whether to interpret modern art objects or accept them as pure objects
Determining what constitutes 'understanding' of minds (general principles vs. every detail)
failures: Modern art's attempt to eliminate interpretation and make objects simply 'be' was a monumental flop
The more viewers are told not to look for meaning, the more mystified they become
Self-defeating nature of using art to teach Zen philosophy through complex codes
aha_moments: Magritte's realization that both pipes in nested paintings exist on the same flat surface, making nesting levels irrelevant
The self-destroying message in Magritte's pipe paintings where verbal message becomes meaningless smudges when fully understood
The backfiring effect where demystification attempts create more mystification through the 'frame effect'
The connection between symbol-object dualism and how minds represent the external world internally
Understanding that modern art's complexity comes from tangled hierarchies of codes about codes
metaphors: Art as operating through 'codes' requiring viewer interpretation
The 'frame effect' - automatic significance imparted by gallery context
Tangled Hierarchy of messages in modern art
Acoustical democracy in Cage's music philosophy
Art's identity crisis as central problem of the century
'ism' as suffix without prefix - ideology without ideas
temporal: Before: music and painting expressed ideas through symbols; After: exploration of capacity to exist without symbolic value
Before: abstract art abandoned representation (revolutionary); After: surrealism returned to representational art for subversive purposes
Before: art was seen as one step removed from reality; After: attempt to eliminate the interpretive step
quotes: It existed for the spectator, as it were, simultaneously in his mind, as both inside the room in the painting, and outside in the real landscape. Which is how we see the world: we see it as being outside ourselves even though it is only a mental representation of it that we experience inside ourselves.
One should no more judge the value of a piano sonata than one should judge the value of a stone, a thunderstorm, or a starfish.
Ceci n'est pas une pipe

extraction.summary: The author argues that understanding consciousness and mental phenomena requires recognizing Strange Loops—self-reinforcing interactions between different levels of brain organization where top levels influence bottom levels and vice versa. Drawing on Gödel's incompleteness theorem, the author suggests that some mental phenomena like consciousness and free will may be intrinsically high-level concepts that cannot be fully explained at lower physical levels alone.
key_claims: Mental representation occurs inside ourselves even though we experience the world as external
Understanding general brain principles is feasible without Gödelian obstacles, unlike understanding every detail of a single brain
Gödel's theorem doesn't prevent artificial intelligence or reproduction of human intelligence through programs
Brains may be intractable systems that don't decompose neatly into explainable layers
Intelligence understanding may be 'accidentally inexplicable' due to our brain's limitation, not fundamental Gödelian reasons
Undecidable propositions require high-level explanations that are impossible at lower levels
Consciousness and free will are candidates for emergent, high-level phenomena
Strange Loops create self-reinforcing resonance between levels, analogous to Henkin sentences
The self emerges when it gains the power to reflect itself
Ideas have causal potency equal to molecules, cells, or nerve impulses
processes: Magritte's paintings lead to understanding the link between symbol function and mind function
Translation from low-level physical hardware descriptions to high-level psychological software descriptions
Level-crossing that occurs at translation points between number-theoretical and metamathematical statements
Upward and downward causality propagating through tangled hierarchies of mentality
decisions: Adopting a reasonable definition of 'understanding' rather than unreasonable one regarding mind comprehension
Distinguishing between understanding general brain working principles versus understanding a single brain in detail
Choosing to view consciousness as potentially explicable through Strange Loop relationships rather than total mystery
Recognizing multiple types of causality (translation-based and physical) in mental explanations
failures: Inability to explain Gödel's undecidable string G using TNT-level explanation methods
Failure of low-level derivations to produce explanations for certain high-level phenomena no matter how lengthy
Brain's possible inability to fully understand itself due to insufficient intelligence capacity
Incompleteness of purely reductionistic descriptions that are incomprehensible to human minds
aha_moments: Gödel's proof demonstrates that high-level views of systems contain explanatory power absent at lower levels
Undecidability is intrinsically tied to requiring a high-level viewpoint for explanation
The analogy between Gödel's incompleteness and consciousness: both involve level-crossing creating explanatory gaps
Self-reflection is the mechanism by which self emerges—consciousness requires self-mirroring
Subjective and objective descriptions of mind (like subjective redness vs. objective wavelength) are reconcilable through Strange Loop perspective
metaphors: Car engine analogy for understanding general brain working principles
Henkin sentence as analogy for self-reinforcing consciousness through self-assertion
Escher's Drawing Hands representing both inside-the-system and outside-the-system perspectives on mind
Peck-order hierarchy metaphor for causal control agents in the brain
Tangled Hierarchy describing the complex level-crossing in mental systems
temporal: Before understanding Gödel-numbering, G appears to have nothing wrong with it; after understanding it, its nontheoremhood becomes clear
Self comes into being at the moment it acquires power to reflect itself
Humans may lie below or above the threshold of intelligence necessary for self-understanding
quotes: The self comes into being at the moment it has the power to reflect itself.

Ideas cause ideas and help evolve new ideas. They interact with each other and with other mental forces in the same brain, in neighboring brains, and, thanks to global communication, in far distant, foreign brains.
The subjective feeling of redness comes from the vortex of self-perception in the brain; the objective wavelength is how you see things when you step back, outside of the system.

extraction.summary: This section explores how ideas and ideals have causal power comparable to physical entities, and argues that free will emerges from the self-symbol's interaction with other mental symbols in a tangled hierarchy where self-knowledge and self-ignorance coexist. The text uses examples ranging from marbles to chess programs to robots to demonstrate that 'choice-making' depends on whether we can identify with a high-level description of a process.
key_claims: Ideas have causal potency as real as molecules, cells, or nerve impulses
Ideas interact with each other and with external surroundings to produce bursts of evolutionary advance
Subjective and objective languages describe the same phenomenon from different perspectives (inside vs outside the system)
Free will results from interaction between the self-symbol and other symbols in the brain
A system makes 'choices' when symbols model the situation and affect the decision
Self-monitoring systems with incomplete self-knowledge generate the feeling of free will
Determinism is irrelevant to whether something is a 'choice maker'
The vortex of self-reference is core to AI and understanding human minds
processes: Robot in T-maze activation: approach decision point → consult self-symbol and internal symbols → activate decider subroutine → output left or right decision
Writer's creative process: form mental images → experiment with different expressions → settle on version while maintaining intuitive rather than complete understanding
Decision-making in systems with self-awareness: external suggestion → channeled into symbol mass → interaction with self-symbol → decision emerges without full transparency
decisions: Replacing 'Does X have free will?' with 'Does X make choices?' as a more tractable question
Not designating marble rolling as 'choice' despite unpredictability because physical laws fully determine behavior
Distinguishing between deterministic and randomized chess programs
Allowing a robot's self-symbol to affect decisions as the key modification enabling choice-like behavior
failures: Standard marbles and deterministic calculators fail to make choices because they lack self-awareness
Chess programs without learning or self-monitoring cannot be said to make choices
A robot with symbols cannot feel it makes choices unless those symbols affect the outcome
Systems cannot be called choice-makers if they lack the ability to model themselves
aha_moments: The subjective sensation and objective wavelength of red are reconcilable when viewed from inside the system versus outside it (like Escher's Drawing Hands)
Free will emerges not from non-determinism but from self-referential systems with incomplete self-knowledge
Meaning enters a system when symbols monitor decisions and affect outcomes
The vortex where self-reference occurs creates both Gödelian tanglement and the feeling of consciousness and will
metaphors: Ideas like molecules, cells, and nerve impulses (causal potency metaphor)
Escher's Drawing Hands as illustration of subjective/objective reconciliation
Marble rolling down bumpy hill (mindless physical determinism)
Fancy marbles rolling down fancy hills (deterministic programs)
Vortex/whirlpool (self-symbol sucking in external suggestions and symbols)
Iceberg (unconscious mental processes hidden beneath conscious awareness)
Tangled Hierarchy and Gödel vortex (self-reference creating strange loops)
Escher's Print Gallery (cyclonic eye of tangled hierarchy illustrating circular levels)
temporal: Before symbols affect decisions, after symbols affect decisions—choice-making capability emerges
Before self-knowledge develops, after self-knowledge develops—different assessments of choice capacity
When a system gains self-monitoring capability—the nature of its decision-making appears to change
quotes: Ideas cause ideas and help evolve new ideas. They interact with each other and with other mental forces in the same brain, in neighboring brains, and, thanks to global communication, in far distant, foreign brains.
From this balance between self-knowledge and self-ignorance comes the feeling of free will.
It is irrelevant whether the system is running deterministically; what makes us call it a 'choice maker' is whether we can identify with a high-level description of the process.

extraction.summary: The text explores Strange Loops and Tangled Hierarchies through artistic and musical examples, particularly Escher's Print Gallery and Bach's Musical Offering, arguing that self-reference and recursive structures are central to understanding both artificial intelligence and human consciousness. The author demonstrates how multiple levels of abstraction can collapse into recursive loops, relating these concepts to Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem.
key_claims: Self-reference and tangled hierarchies will be at the core of AI and understanding human minds
The number of levels perceived in a Strange Loop is determined by what feels natural, varying by context and preference
Escher's Print Gallery is a pictorial parable for Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem
The center of Print Gallery must be incomplete and cannot be eliminated without violating the drawing rules
Observers outside a self-referential system can know things those inside cannot
Shepard tones allow the Endlessly Rising Canon to return to its starting pitch while seeming to ascend indefinitely
Bach's Musical Offering contains hidden layers and patterns that reward deep analysis
The Musical Offering is a fugue of fugues, a Tangled Hierarchy similar to those of Escher and Gödel
processes: Shepard tone scale construction: play parallel scales in multiple octave ranges with independently weighted notes, gradually fading the top octave while bringing in the bottom octave to reproduce the starting pitch
Analyzing Print Gallery: recognizing three kinds of 'in-ness' - physical inclusion, artistic depiction, and mental representation
decisions: Choosing where to perceive levels in Strange Loops is a matter of intuition and aesthetic preference
Deciding whether to collapse or expand the number of intermediate levels in a loop structure
failures: Bach's original Endlessly Rising Canon returns an octave higher rather than at exact original pitch
Incomplete center of Print Gallery appears as a 'blemish' or defect, though the defect lies in expectations rather than execution
aha_moments: Recognition that the arbitrary division markers in hierarchical diagrams can be eliminated or added without changing the fundamental self-referential structure
Realization that observers outside a system can perceive its incompleteness while those inside cannot
Discovery that Shepard tones solve the problem of creating a truly closed auditory loop
Insight that Bach may have been aware of Shepard tone principles centuries before their formal discovery
metaphors: Strange Loops as cyclonic 'eyes' of Tangled Hierarchies
Print Gallery as a vortex where levels cross and collapse into self-reference
Musical Offering as a 'fugue of fugues' and an 'Eternal Golden Braid'
Human mind as a 'beautiful many-voiced fugue'
Gödel, Escher, and Bach as three intertwoven strands forming a braid
temporal: Before Shepard tones: Endlessly Rising Canon returned an octave higher
After Shepard tones discovered: true closed loops became possible in music
Escher's work predates formal understanding of its connection to Gödel's theorem, yet embodies the principle
Bach's Musical Offering was created centuries before Shepard tones were formally identified, yet contains similar principles
quotes: I think it will eventually turn out to be at the core of AI, and the focus of all attempts to understand how human minds work.
Where one perceives the levels is a matter of intuition and esthetic preference.
Thus we, on the outside, can know that Print Gallery is essentially incomplete-a fact which the young man, on the inside, can never know.

extraction.summary: A philosophical dialogue exploring free will, determinism, and the nature of reality through the conceit of characters discovering they exist within a book authored by Douglas Hofstadter. The conversation progresses from discussing 'smart-stupid' computers and their potential for intelligence to meta-textual revelations about the characters' own fictional nature.
key_claims: Television screens are a new kind of flexible computer called 'smart-stupids' with potential to be either intelligent or unintelligent depending on instruction
A sufficiently well-instructed smart-stupid could theoretically play chess or hold conversations indistinguishable from human interaction
Intelligent machines will likely be as confused about consciousness and free will as humans are
Free will can exist even if one's mind is software running in another being's hardware
Characters in dialogues can have apparent autonomy and wills of their own despite being authored creations
Dream characters and fictitious beings operate as software suborganisms within a host organism's universe
All entities, including authors, may themselves be software subprocesses in higher-order systems
processes: Instructing smart-stupids with sufficient skill to perform complex tasks like playing chess or conversing
Recognition of patterns in dialogue structure (time symmetry, reverse ordering of statements)
Host organism undergoing state changes that cause suborganism disintegration (e.g., waking from dreams)
decisions: Whether Achilles will accept the idea that he is a character in a dialogue
Whether free will is compatible with being authored or determined
Who deserves authorship credit for works written by fictional characters
failures: Lack of virtuosos capable of truly mastering smart-stupid instruction
Author's chronic lateness to appointments
Achilles's initial resistance to accepting his own fictional nature
aha_moments: Recognition that talking animals in the dialogue are anomalous and indicate fictional context
Discovery of time-symmetrical structure in park conversation with the Tortoise
Realization upon reading transcript that all dialogue was pre-planned by an author
Understanding that multiple levels of authorship could exist recursively
Conceptualization that dream characters, software entities, and fictional characters share similar ontological status
metaphors: Smart-stupids as new types of computers with flexibility to be smart or stupid
Walking up a familiar staircase and continuing past what seemed to be the top
Waking from dreams to find reality was itself a dream (recursive dreaming)
Characters as sand castles that vanish when waves (state changes) wash over them
Hiccups and dream characters as software suborganisms within a host organism/universe
Consciousness and identity as patterns in sand that persist even after dissolution
temporal: Before: Achilles believed in his own autonomy and physical reality; After: Achilles discovers he is a character in a book
Before: The park conversation seemed random; After: Revealed to have been deliberately authored with specific symmetries
Before: Achilles thought smart-stupids were mere toys; After: Recognized as potential vehicles for machine intelligence
Before: Characters existed unaware of higher authorial reality; After: Confronted with author and recursive levels of reality
quotes: When intelligent machines are constructed, we should not be surprised to find them as confused and as stubborn as men in their convictions about mind-matter, consciousness, free will, and the like. - Marvin Minsky
Your will can be equally free, if your brain is just a piece of software inside someone else's hardware brain. And their brain, too, may be software in a yet higher brain...
Once my characters are formed, they seem to have lives of their own, and I need to exert very little effort in planning their lines. - The Author

extraction.summary: In this dialogue from Hofstadter's Gödel, Escher, Bach, the famous mathematician Charles Babbage arrives at the Crab's residence and demonstrates the capabilities of the Crab's 'smart-stupids' (computers modeled on the Analytical Engine). Babbage showcases various computational abilities including calculating pi digits, generating graphics, and programming a chess-playing algorithm, all while the characters engage in playful wordplay and explore themes of machine intelligence.
key_claims: Charles Babbage was a pioneer of computing and the Analytical Engine
The 'smart-stupids' are streamlined realizations of the Analytical Engine
Babbage can calculate thousands of digits of pi with a tiny algorithm
A chess-playing program can simultaneously play multiple opponents
La Mettrie wrote L'homme machine in 1747 about man as a machine
The Theme explores imbuing machines with human mental faculties like intelligence
The chess algorithm demonstrates that smart-stupids can be intelligent
processes: Babbage inputs commands via keyboard to calculate pi
Graphics generation through keyboard commands with color spectrum display
Chess program setup allowing multiple simultaneous games with standard chess notation input
Troubleshooting smart-stupid connections by checking input leads
Internal chess-fugue: two subprograms play each other while third plays against external opponent
decisions: Whether to have Babbage demonstrate the smart-stupids versus other activities
Choosing between graphics or other demonstrations
Deciding who plays chess and how to involve all participants
Implementing a three-part chess game structure with internal and external players
failures: Babbage's chess algorithm has weaknesses that the Crab easily exploits
Smart-stupids experiencing extraneous flashes and screen disturbances from loose input leads
Babbage's limited skill in programming prevents giving the chess algorithm more power
aha_moments: The realization that one could calculate so many digits of pi so quickly with a tiny algorithm
Recognition that Babbage plays smart-stupids as if they were musical instruments
The concept of a three-part chess-fugue combining internal and external games
Understanding that the obverse of La Mettrie's man-as-machine is machine-with-human-intelligence
metaphors: Smart-stupids as musical instruments that Babbage plays with skill
Three-part chess-fugue as a musical analogy for simultaneous games
L'homme machine contrasted with machine intelligence as two sides of the same coin
Computing as analogous to musical composition and performance
temporal: La Mettrie's L'homme machine written in 1747 at Frederick the Great's court
Babbage has grown fond of street instruments over the past hundred years
The smart-stupids having recently been delivered and hardly tested before this evening
A quarter hour passes while characters are engaged in different activities
quotes: I can get along very well without such a program. Relax; I Can Enjoy Random Concerts And Recitals.
My role was merely to see what was already potentially present in it, and to exploit its instruction set in a moderately efficient manner.
You play the smart-stupids as if they were musical instruments, Mr. Babbage!

extraction.summary: A dialogue involving Babbage, Turing, and others explores the nature of artificial intelligence and consciousness through a test where characters attempt to distinguish between a human programmer and a simulated intelligence. The conversation demonstrates recursive role reversals and the difficulty of determining what is 'real' versus programmed, illustrated through references to Escher's work and the concept of Strange Loops.
key_claims: Intelligent machines can exhibit confusion about consciousness and free will similar to humans
A test can be designed where an interrogator attempts to identify which entity is programmed versus which is the programmer
Both a human and a program can plausibly claim to have created the other, creating epistemic uncertainty
The nature of reality and programming is fundamentally ambiguous in systems with mutual recursion
Dialogues can be structured like musical fugues with each character introducing a theme
processes: Design a remote interrogation test where Babbage and Turing are separated and answer questions anonymously
Tortoise poses questions to both entities via keyboard to determine which is the program and which is the programmer
Analyze responses for patterns that reveal mechanical versus conscious behavior
decisions: Babbage decides to attempt multiplying his own intelligence sixfold rather than the Crab's intelligence
The group decides to conduct the Turing test to determine which entity is the program
Characters attempt to identify the program based on response patterns
failures: Babbage's attempt to create a program fails to produce definitively distinguishable results
The Turing test fails to provide clear answers about which entity is programmed
Poetry attempts by one entity (writing a limerick instead of sonnet) could indicate programming but remain ambiguous
aha_moments: Recognition that both entities can claim to have programmed the other with equal plausibility
Understanding that Strange Loops create irreducible ambiguity about which entity is 'real'
Realization that the Escher Drawing Hands analogy perfectly captures mutual programming relationships
Insight that consciousness and free will cannot be definitively determined through interrogation alone
metaphors: Drawing Hands by Escher - represents mutual creation where each entity creates the other
Strange Loops - illustrates self-referential systems that create paradoxes about reality
Chess game - represents competition between human and machine intelligence
Fugue structure - represents how multiple voices can interweave while maintaining individual themes
temporal: Before the test: uncertainty about which entity is real
During the test: interrogation attempts to reveal true nature through responses
After the test: roles reverse, creating deeper uncertainty about reality and programming
quotes: Nothing is realer than that. But rather than quibble with me, why don't you try my program out?
Each of two hands draws the other, just as each of two people (or automata) has programmed the other!
The most important idea is that there should be a single theme which is stated by each different 'voice', or character, upon entering, just as in a musical fugue.
domain_terms: Fugue (musical form with multiple interweaving voices)
Consciousness (disputed quality of programs versus humans)

extraction.summary: The author discusses the structure and content of their book combining Escher, Gödel, and Bach through dialogues that imitate Bach's musical forms. The characters explore how self-reference, fugal devices, and recursive themes work in both music and language, with the final dialogue structured as a six-part ricercar.
key_claims: Dialogues alternate with chapters, with each dialogue imitating a Bach composition
Fugues are defined by their thematic entries, not necessarily by fugal devices like retrograde motion or inversion
Indirect self-reference is more general and stimulating than direct self-reference
No reference is truly direct; all reference depends on some kind of coding scheme
Gödel numbering demonstrates how self-reference can be achieved through coding without formalizing quotation
Being a good improviser may be incompatible with knowing how one does it
Modulation between keys has a counterpart in dialogues where topic changes while theme remains invariant
processes: Creating dialogues that imitate musical fugues: state a theme with each character/voice, then branch into freer conversation
Using fugal devices in verbal form: retrogression (Crab Canon), inversion and augmentation (Sloth Canon)
Creating acronyms that create infinite regress through self-reference (RACRECIR example)
Imitating Bach's six-part ricercar structure by thinning texture to three voices for portions of dialogue
Creating modulations in dialogue: changing topics while keeping abstract theme invariant, eventually cycling back to original topic
decisions: Use indirect self-reference through reader connection rather than characters talking directly about their own dialogue
Imitate Gödel's indirect self-referential construction through isomorphism rather than direct quotation
Represent the King's Theme through the Crab's Theme in the dialogue
Have only three characters interact during certain dialogue sections to match the three-voice texture thinning in Bach's piece
failures: Direct character commentary on their own dialogue would wreck the beauty of the structural scheme
Some canons are poorly constructed and not equally comprehensible to the ear
Retrograde motion in canons is elusive to perception, unlike inversion which is recognizable
aha_moments: The realization that Escher's Drawing Hands illustrates Strange Loops through mutual programming
Understanding that fugal entries are what make a fugue a fugue, not the fugal devices
Recognition that all self-reference is ultimately indirect because every reference depends on coding schemes
The insight that improvisation may require not understanding how one does it
metaphors: Strange Loops - illustrated by Escher's Drawing Hands where two hands draw each other
Fugue structure applied to dialogue - characters as voices entering with themes
Musical modulation as a metaphor for topic changes that preserve abstract theme
Gödel numbering as a coding system enabling self-reference without direct quotation
temporal: Before the current dialogue, Babbage had left and others were flesh-and-blood creatures; now they are images on screen
Before LISP, self-referential programming required indirect methods; LISP allows direct self-reference through program-data identity
Before formalizing quotation, Gödel used numbering; the author argues both achieve self-reference through coding
quotes: The whole point of Gödel-numbering is that it shows how even WITHOUT formalizing quotation, one can get self-reference: through a code.
No reference is truly direct-every reference depends on SOME kind of coding scheme. It's just a question of how implicit it is.
Perhaps being a good improviser is incompatible with knowing how one does it.

extraction.summary: This is a bibliography and notes section from a comprehensive academic work covering mathematics, logic, artificial intelligence, and related philosophy. The section provides citations organized by chapter and a curated bibliography with author commentary on selected works.
key_claims: Gödel's 1931 article included a Roman numeral 'I' signifying intention for follow-up work, but the second paper was never written due to widespread acclaim of the first
Terry Winograd's procedural model of language understanding influenced AI dialogue development
LISP became the dominant computer language for Artificial Intelligence research for two decades
decisions: Bibliography uses asterisks to mark prime motivators (double asterisk) versus books with special features (single asterisk)
Meta-pointers chosen over direct technical literature pointers to provide accessibility
temporal: LISP dominated AI research for two decades
Gödel's 1931 article intended to be followed by a second paper but this pattern was disrupted
quotes: The presence of two asterisks indicates that the hook or article was a prime motivator of my book.
I have not given many direct pointers into technical literature; instead I have chosen to give 'meta-pointers'

extraction.summary: This is a bibliography section containing annotated references on mathematics, logic, artificial intelligence, music, art, and cognitive science. The entries range from foundational works on Gödel's Theorem and mathematical logic to books on pattern recognition, artificial intelligence critiques, and artistic explorations of recursion.
key_claims: Bongard problems are puzzles for testing pattern recognition capabilities in humans and machines
M.C. Escher's work captures the spirit of Gödel's Theorem in visual form
The halting problem is unsolvable in any language containing conditionals and recursive function definitions
Gödel's Theorem assumes new meaning when connected to algorithmic definitions of randomness and simplicity
Various statements in set theory are undecidable within usual formalisms
Pattern recognition and face recognition require specific information representation in memory
processes: Fitzpatrick's exposition of Gödel's proof using three different languages to distinguish relevant levels
Algorithmic approaches to randomness and mathematical proof
Recursive thinking in LISP as described in The Little Lisper
Computer chess programming strategies and evaluation methods
decisions: Whether to use the word 'consciousness' in scientific explanations of animal behavior
How to determine categories in ill-defined spaces (Bongard's concern)
Decision points about what constitutes valid evidence in scientific inquiry
failures: Anti-AI arguments and critiques from figures like Dreyfus, despite their irritation value
Computer chess programs that don't work and their limitations
Difficulty in drawing explicit connections between music and human emotion
aha_moments: Word frequency analysis reveals fascinating things about thought processes
The concept that absence of meaning becomes profoundly meaningful in modern art
Gödel's undecidability results can be understood through multiple linguistic frameworks
Escher's recursive art demonstrates abstract logical principles visually
metaphors: Escher comes about as close as one can to recursion in art
